content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Questions: How does the experiment you conducted relate to light, constellations, and light pollution? Conclude the impact of light pollution on the environment.

content.text: You already know that some of the sources of environmental pollution are cars, thermal power plants, and industrial enterprises. But other sources lead to light pollution that can make stargazing difficult.

Light pollution is the illumination of the night by artificial light sources (electric lamps, fire, etc.), interfering with astronomical observations and changing the biorhythms of living organisms. It represents excessive use of outdoor light and has many harmful effects on the environment.
To better understand the process of light pollution, let's conduct a small experiment.

Conditions and materials for the experiment: The room where the experiment will be carried out should have curtains on the windows to darken the room so that no artificial light comes in and it is possible to control the amount of light received and the light source (flashlight). A flashlight, a sheet of thick paper of a dark (black) color, scissors, a pencil, a pin or paper clip for fixation, and adhesive tape (duct tape, tape).
Using scissors, cut a piece of dark paper into a circle so that it is larger than the front of your flashlight.
Using pencils or a pen, make several holes in the piece of paper. The holes should resemble your zodiac sign constellations (Aries, Sagittarius, Capricorn, etc.) or as you wish.
Tightly attach the paper ready for the experiment to the front of the flashlight with adhesive tape (duct tape, tape) so that there is no gap at the edges.
Take the flashlight to a darkened room.
Turn on the flashlight and aim the light at the ceiling. If you don't see anything on the ceiling, you will need to enlarge the holes on the paper.
Then point the flashlight back at the ceiling and use curtains or blinds to add some light to the room. Observe how your constellations are visible.
Repeat the experiment, but subject to increased lighting of the room.
Record your observations in the table.
Try to leave comments on your observations in this experiment.

Throughout this week, conduct an experiment with your family to analyze how much food you are wasting.
You‚Äôll need: a bucket and a scale

Before you add anything to the bucket, weigh it to find your starting weight that you‚Äôll deduct later. You‚Äôre tasked with tracking the amount of food left on the plates of everyone in your family after dinner for a week. Do this by adding anything left on the plates to the bucket. There are 52 weeks in a year. Multiply the weight you got by 52 to find your estimated amount of food wasted per year in your household. Then, divide this number by the number of people in your household to find the average amount of food wasted per person.

content.text: There are a huge number of physical bodies and things in nature. One of the ‚Äúsubstances‚Äù in our world that has many different interesting properties is water. Let's conduct an experiment using water, with the help of which you can see the process of cohesion, when molecules of the same substance are attracted to each other, which gives water a unique property - surface tension.

It also happens in nature when molecules of different substances stick together. This process is called adhesion. This is the force of attraction that holds two dissimilar materials in contact in the area of their contact.
Pre-experiment question: How many drops do you think the young researcher needs to put on the coin before it breaks and the paper sinks?
You‚Äôll need: A coin, A pipette, Water in a cap, Paper towel
Pour water into the Petri dish.
Carefully place a piece of paper/napkin on the surface of the water. What are you observing?
Carefully place a coin in the center of the paper. What are you observing?
Fill the pipette with water.
Hold the dropper over the coin and begin to slowly drip water onto the coin without stopping dripping.
Count the number of drops you put on the coin.
Continue adding droplets to the coin until the paper rips and the coin sinks.
What conclusions can be drawn about the surface tension of water?
In which of the experiments did you observe the process of cohesion and adhesion?
Post-experiment questions: How many drops of water needed to be dropped onto the coin for the paper to tear? Were you surprised by the results of your experiment?

content.text: Have you ever heard of the Tragedy of the Commons? To put it simply, this is an environmental problem where when people have access to a shared resource, they act in their own interest. This can result in overconsumption and ultimate depletion of this resource.
With this in mind, read about the following situation and answer the questions that follow.

A local pond has been discovered by a nearby fisherman, that previously no one knew existed. The fisherman casts his line in the pond and finds there is a huge population of big trout. Everytime he casts a line, he gets a bite, and the supply of fish seems to never run out.

At the end of his fishing day, he had pounds and pounds of trout to take to the market. People flocked to his stand at the market, marveling at the huge trout for sale. Feeling boisterous, the fisherman tells everyone he found a secret pond with endless trout.
Day after day, the fisherman brings pounds of trout to the market. But, slowly, less and less people buy the trout. The fisherman is confused, but soon realizes the problem.

The next day, when he returns to the pond, crowds of people are there, casting their lines. People came with trucks to load trout into, filling it to the brim. The fisherman is upset, knowing his secret is out. He becomes worried as the amount of trout leaving the pond seems like too much for the pond to handle.

He realizes that since no one has to pay for the trout coming out of the pond if they get it themselves, they will consume great amounts without any worry. Also, no one is going to pay for his fish as long as they can get it out of this pond so easily.
He returns to the pond day after day for a week, getting there earlier and earlier, but everytime, there‚Äôs a crowd big enough that he can barely reach the water edge.

A few days later, disappointed, he returns to the pond. He doesn‚Äôt get there early. He arrives later in the day, not seeing a point in rushing there. When he arrives, there‚Äôs no crowd. Perplexed, he decides to cast a line and see what happens.
He waits and waits, and nothing bites. He waits longer and longer, until he gives up.
He goes back day after day, trying to get a bite, with no luck.
